channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Italy Bridge Collapse Leaves 37 Dead
item.media:description: The collapsed section of the A10 highway, a major east-west artery through the port city, near where the bridge crossed the Polcevera River.
item.description: Buildings and vehicles were crushed by the collapse in Genoa, while some people somehow survived. An official said that the bridge had shown previous “signs of problems.”
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI, ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Trump’s Trade War Is Rattling China’s Leaders
item.media:description: A Chinese investor at a brokerage house in Beijing on Thursday. Worry over the economy has led to a torrent of criticism online, some of it directed at Mr. Xi’s leadership.
item.description: While President Xi Jinping remains firmly in charge, friction with the Trump administration and troubles at home have dented his political dominance.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Turks Scramble as Lira Falls and Prices Soar
item.media:description: People waiting outside a currency exchange office in Istanbul on Wednesday. The Turkish lira has lost 25 percent of its value since last week.
item.description: Some businesses have doubled prices on imported goods this year and are already feeling a falloff in sales, as economists warn of galloping inflation.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: The Interpreter: Turkey’s Crisis Exposes the Perils of Strongman Rule
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s government encouraged firms to spend heavily on foreign loans. The debt has created a currency crisis.
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan appears to be going down the same ill-fated path that was taken by the failed authoritarian leaders of Venezuela and Zimbabwe.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: The Afghan Army’s Last Stand at Chinese Camp
item.media:description: Afghan National Army soldiers from the 209th Corps march on their base in Mazar-i-Sharif, Afghanistan, in 2015.
item.description: “We all think they have sold us out to the enemy,” an Afghan army captain said of his top commanders before he was killed by the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: After Children Die in Pit Toilets, South Africa Vows to Fix School Sanitation
item.media:description: A student walking into one of the few working bathrooms at a school in rural Nkomazi, Mpumalanga province in South Africa.
item.description: A crisis in South African schools has stirred outrage about corruption and severe inequality.
item.dc:creator: KIMON de GREEF

item.title: London Driver Held in Terrorism Inquiry After Car Crash Near Parliament
item.media:description: Police officers near the site where a car crashed outside the Houses of Parliament in London on Tuesday.
item.description: The motorist, identified only as a man in his late 20s, injured several cyclists and pedestrians, the police said.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Israeli Airport Detention of Prominent U.S. Jewish Journalist Prompts Uproar
item.media:description: Peter Beinart, an author and CNN contributor, was interrogated at the airport in Tel Aviv on Sunday about his political activities.
item.description: After several left-wing activists were held for questioning at Israel’s borders, questions arise over the powers and purposes of its security agencies.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Where to Go in Paris? The Red-Topped Trash Can
item.media:description: A new type of urinal, on Ile St. Louis in Paris. “The enemy is not the urinal,” its designer said of criticism, “it’s the urine everywhere.”
item.description: The city keeps trying to stop men from urinating in public, but the latest urinal design has drawn anger from well-heeled residents.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and ELIAN PELTIER

item.title: Bus Crash Kills 24 in Ecuador
item.media:description: Rescue workers near the bus that crashed on Tuesday about two hours from Quito.
item.description: A bus apparently lost its brakes, then hit another vehicle at high speed before smashing into several houses.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S.-Turkey Tensions Could Stall Progress Against ISIS, Officials Say
item.media:description: American troops driving from the Kurdish-controlled city of Manbij, in Syria, toward their outpost near the Turkish border.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: Joint operations between American and Turkish troops are still being planned. But officials worry about Turkey’s reliability as a battlefield partner.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Catholic Church, Turkey, Omarosa Manigault Newman: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: Seven of the Deadliest Infrastructure Failures Throughout History
item.media:description: A bridge on the New York State Thruway over Schoharie Creek collapsed in 1987. Ten people died, prompting an investigation into the bridge’s construction.
item.description: A bridge collapse in Italy that killed at least 20 people was the latest disaster to raise worries about aging or improperly built bridges, dams and other structures.
item.dc:creator: JULIA JACOBS

item.title: Gridlock on the Brooklyn Bridge? Blame El Chapo
item.media:description: Every few months or so, the police must close the entire Brooklyn Bridge when Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo, is called to court in Brooklyn. And that’s just now. His trial begins in November.
item.description: For months, the bridge has been closed whenever Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug kingpin, goes to court. The judge has worked out a solution to the problem, but he did not reveal it.
item.dc:creator: ALAN FEUER

item.title: Parents of Austin Tice, Journalist Seized in Syria, Are Confident He’s Alive
item.media:description: Marc and Debra Tice, the parents Austin Tice, a journalist kidnapped in Syria six years ago, at a July 2017 news conference in Beirut, Lebanon.
item.description: Marc and Debra Tice, whose son, Austin, has been missing in Syria since Aug. 14, 2012, said the Trump administration was committed to bringing him home.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Iraqi Leader Offers to Help Family of Spy Who Infiltrated ISIS
item.media:description: Capt. Harith al-Sudani’s wife, Raghad Hasan Chaloob, and their three children, at home in Baghdad.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: Relatives of the spy, who was killed behind enemy lines, have struggled to receive death benefits without his body as legal proof of death.
item.dc:creator: MARGARET COKER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Indigenous Australians Use Tech to Expose Police Abuse
item.media:description: Friends and relatives of David Dungay Jr. at a rally last December outside the prison in Sydney, Australia, where he died in 2015. In a video recording, Mr. Dungay, a 26-year-old Indigenous Australian, screams “I can’t breathe” at least 12 times to the guards pinning him down.
item.description: Copwatch teaches Australia’s Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples how to use their mobile phones’ cameras to battle police brutality.
item.dc:creator: GIOVANNI TORRE

item.title: Genoa Bridge Collapse: Video Shows Moment Road Fell
item.description: The structure broke apart, falling nearly 150 feet. We spoke to a local journalist who described the aftermath.

item.title: Turkish President Calls for Boycott of U.S. Electronics Including the iPhone
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, center, using an iPhone in Istanbul in May. He urged his country on Tuesday not to buy American products, saying, “If they have the iPhone, there is Samsung” as an alternative.
item.description: The remarks by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan come as the country grapples with a worsening economic crisis and a widening diplomatic dispute with the United States.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: In New Zealand, Avocado Shortage Leads to Orchard Crime Wave
item.media:description: Because of strict biosecurity laws, New Zealand does not import avocados, and the fruit’s popularity (combined with bad harvests) has led to what an industry representative called “opportunistic” thefts.
item.description: With prices for the fruit soaring after two years of low harvests, growers are experiencing a raft of thefts and black markets have sprung up to distribute the spoils.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-McLAY

item.title: Talk on Hong Kong Independence Goes Ahead, Despite Criticism
item.media:description: Andy Chan, center, founder of the pro-independence Hong Kong National Party, leaving the Foreign Correspondents’ Club in Hong Kong after delivering a speech on Tuesday.
item.description: Officials had criticized the Foreign Correspondents’ Club of Hong Kong for hosting a talk by the founder of a party the government wants to ban.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: South Korea’s #MeToo Movement Dealt Blow by Politician’s Acquittal
item.media:description: Ahn Hee-jung, center, was the most prominent figure to be accused of sexual misconduct since the #MeToo movement gained force in South Korea. Kim Ji-eun, right, his former secretary, accused him of rape.
item.description: Ahn Hee-jung was the most prominent public figure to be accused of sexual misconduct since the #MeToo movement gained force in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Why Is the U.S. Wary of a Declaration to End the Korean War?
item.media:description: President Trump and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, in Singapore in June. The two sides have clashed over just what their agreement at the summit meeting means.
item.description: Both North Korea and South Korea want to start the process toward a peace treaty in the decades-long war, but Washington is standing in the way.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Why the Taliban’s Assault on Ghazni Matters
item.media:description: Afghan security forces and Afghan militia members on a road in Ghazni Province during clashes between Taliban militants and Afghan security forces on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Mohammad Anwar Danishyar/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The Taliban besieged yet another major Afghan city, this time less than 100 miles from the country’s capital city, Kabul.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Turkey, Trump, Primaries: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: LOUIS LUCERO II and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: Ouster of Zuma Loyalist Bolsters South Africa’s Corruption Fight
item.media:description: Shaun Abrahams, center, South Africa’s top prosecutor, was ordered to step down immediately by the country’s highest court.
item.media:credit: Wikus De Wet/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The country’s chief prosecutor, a close ally of ex-president Jacob Zuma, was told to step down, clearing the way for the Ramaphosa administration to take a tougher stance on graft.
item.dc:creator: KIMON de GREEF

item.title: Iran’s Top Leader Faults Rouhani for Crisis, Saying He Crossed ‘Red Lines’
item.media:description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, sharply criticized the country’s president during remarks in Tehran on Monday.
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei went further than he had before in blaming President Hassan Rouhani for the failing nuclear deal and Iran’s economic travails.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Erdogan Faces a Challenge He Can’t Easily Bully: Turkey’s Economy
item.media:description: A mosque under construction on Taksim Square in Istanbul.
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.description: Turks are bracing for more financial turmoil. Economists warn that the problem is broader and deeper than a spat with the United States.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Another Surprise Meeting With Putin. This Time, It’s Merkel.
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany at their last face-to-face meeting, in Sochi, Russia, in May.
item.description: The German chancellor will meet with the Russian president as their countries seek to cooperate on issues like Syria and a shared gas pipeline.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: U.S. Set to Return Philippine Bells That Once Tolled to Mark a Massacre
item.media:description: Residents dressed up as American soldiers guarded mock bells during a re-enactment of the battle between Filipino and American soldiers in 1901 in Balangiga, Philippines.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: Their ringing set off the worst U.S. defeat in the Philippine-American war and spurred retaliation that left thousands dead. But some objection to their return remains.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Muthuvel Karunanidhi, 94, Screenwriter Turned Politician, Dies
item.media:description: Muthuvel Karunanidhi in 2006, when he was chief minister of Tamil Nadu, after presenting a silk shawl to the president of the Indian National Congress party, Sonia Gandhi, in New Delhi.
item.description: India’s longest-serving legislator, he challenged the caste system’s hold on his country, first in cinema and later in politics.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB

item.title: As Taliban Fight for Ghazni City in Afghanistan, Nearby Districts Fall
item.media:description: Afghan soldiers in the city of Ghazni on Sunday. Government forces, supported by American military airstrikes and some American ground forces, continued on Monday to hold government buildings, the Police Headquarters and prison, and military bases.
item.description: Only two or the province’s 18 rural districts were confirmed to be fully in government control on Monday, as insurgents took over new areas without much of a fight.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: ‘No Such Thing’: China Denies U.N. Reports of Uighur Detention Camps
item.media:description: Chinese military police at a rally in Hotan, Xinjiang, last year. Beijing has progressively tightened security in the region.
item.description: Confronted with accusations of mass internment in the Xinjiang region, Chinese officials refused to answer “questions which are not factual.”
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Pier Collapse at Spain’s Vigo Music Festival Injures More Than 300
item.media:description: The pier in Vigo, Spain, on Monday. Its middle section collapsed around midnight Sunday, injuring hundreds of people at a rap concert.
item.description: The accident occurred in the northwestern city of Vigo during a closing concert by the Spanish rap artist Rels B. No fatalities were reported.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Bui Tin, Colonel Who Accepted South Vietnam’s Surrender, Dies at 90
item.media:description: Bui Tin, second from right, with an unidentified United States Air Force sergeant, as American troops evacuated Saigon in 1973.
item.description: He had a prominent role in the Vietnam War’s final moments, but he later fled the country and became an unlikely critic of its ruling Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Japan Dispatch: Mount Fuji’s Got Mail. A Bone-Rattling Bulldozer Ride Brings It Down.
item.media:description: The summit of Mount Fuji, Japan’s highest mountain, is reached by some 300,000 hikers each year. Many of them visit the mountaintop post office.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Social media dominates communication in Japan, except atop the country’s best-known volcano. But hauling all those postcards off the summit isn’t easy.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Plunge in Lira, Turkey’s Currency, Fuels Fears of Financial Contagion
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s increasingly authoritarian rule in Turkey has fueled concerns about the country’s economic prospects.
item.media:credit: Turkish Presidential Press service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The country’s economic crisis has been caused by soaring inflation, economic mismanagement by the Turkish government and tensions with the United States.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING and ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: North and South Korea Agree to Summit on Dismantling Weapons
item.media:description: Unification Minister Cho Myoung-gyon of South Korea, center, crossing into North Korea on Monday for a meeting in the truce village of Panmunjom. The two sides agreed their leaders would meet again next month.
item.description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea will visit Pyongyang, the capital of North Korea, next month to hold his third summit meeting with Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Hospital Blaze in Taiwan Kills 9 and Injures Dozens
item.media:description: Rescuers evacuating hospital patients after a fire broke out at Taipei Hospital in New Taipei City on Monday.
item.description: The fire broke out in the early morning hours in a room for patients with chronic or long-term illnesses.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON

item.title: In Jordan, Shootout Kills 4 From Security Forces and 3 Militants
item.media:description: Security forces near a damaged building in the city of Salt, Jordan, where a raid killed three militants. Four security personnel also died in the assault.
item.description: In a huge security operation, Jordanian forces laid siege to a building in a residential part of the city of Salt in search of those responsible for an earlier bomb attack on a police van.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Trump’s National Security Claim for Tariffs Sets Off Crisis at W.T.O.
item.media:description: The World Trade Organization’s headquarters in Geneva. The group has been thrust into an uncomfortable position by President Trump’s sweeping steel and aluminum tariffs.
item.media:credit: Aurélien Bergot for The New York Times
item.description: The Trump administration has forced the World Trade Organization into the tough spot of having to make a ruling that could cause problems whatever it does.
item.dc:creator: ANA SWANSON and JACK EWING

item.title: In Thailand, ‘Obesity in Our Monks Is a Ticking Time Bomb’
item.media:description: Buddhist monks collecting alms last month in Bangkok. Devotees’ abundant offerings of sugary or high-fat foods are contributing to a weight problem among monks.
item.media:credit: Amanda Mustard for The New York Times
item.description: Almost half of Thailand’s Buddhist monks are obese, a study found. The government has asked devotees to put healthier food in their daily offerings to slim waistlines.
item.dc:creator: MUKTITA SUHARTONO

item.title: China Seeks Influence in Europe, One Business Deal at a Time
item.media:description: The Chinese president Xi Jinping, center right, welcoming Milos Zeman, his Czech counterpart, center left, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing in 2015. Ye Jianming, far left, headed CEFC China Energy, which spent more than $1 billion on deals in the Czech Republic.
item.media:credit: Lucie Mikolaskova/Czech News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: A mysterious Chinese company went on a buying binge in the Czech Republic following Xi Jinping’s call for greater sway in the region. What was the cost?
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA, MARC SANTORA and ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: A Gas Pipeline to Italy? Five Star Backers Sense a Betrayal
item.media:description: Opponents fear the 545-mile, $5.2 billion gas pipeline running from the Caspian Sea through Italy would disturb the beach in San Foca, Italy.
item.media:credit: Stephanie Gengotti for The New York Times
item.description: The populist party came to power after a campaign filled with conspiratorial overtones against globalist forces. Now it faces one of its first tests of real-life governing.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: In Syria, Explosion in Residential Building Kills Dozens in Rebel-Held Area
item.media:description: Buildings destroyed by an explosion on Sunday in Sarmada, in the rebel-held Syrian province of Idlib.
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: An explosion in a residential building thought to be storing weapons and ammunition in the rebel-held province of Idlib killed at least 69 people, including 12 children, a war monitor said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)

item.title: Russia and 4 Other Nations Settle Decades-long Dispute Over Caspian Sea
item.media:description: The leaders of Iran, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Russia and Turkmenistan in Aktau, Kazakhstan, on Sunday after signing an agreement on the status of the Caspian Sea.
item.description: The five states with shorelines on the Caspian Sea agreed on a formula to divide up the world’s largest inland body of water, potentially clearing the way for oil and gas development.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Convention on the Legal Status of the Caspian Sea

item.title: Taliban Kill More Than 200 Afghan Defenders on 4 Fronts: ‘a Catastrophe’
item.media:description: An Afghan soldier at a checkpoint on the Ghazni highway, in Maidan Shar, Afghanistan, on Sunday.
item.description: The fighting demonstrated that the insurgents had a capacity for carrying out ambitious operations on multiple fronts, while the government struggled to respond on a single front in Ghazni.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND, FAHIM ABED and MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Manchester Shooting That Injured at Least 10 Is Investigated as Attempted Murder
item.media:description: The shooting in Manchester, England, took place early Sunday, hours after the first day of an annual Caribbean carnival had ended.
item.description: The wounded, including children, were treated at hospitals for shotgun injuries sustained after a Caribbean carnival, the police said.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
